Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetPackage_thumb.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetDialog_thumb.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetDialog_thumb.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-1.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-1.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'<a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetPackage.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="NuGet Package" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetPackage_thumb.png" alt="NuGet Package" width="397" height="429" border="0" /></a>(WARNING: This post is machine-translated. A proper translation is in the works). &nbsp; The issue is far from new NuGet-in fact, nowadays it is almost impossible to create a project in Visual Studio that does not have any packages NuGet in use. However, for more convenient that these packages might be, the truth is that few teams have created packages to share their libraries of internal use by finding that a lot of work. Did you know that create a package NuGet for internal use library is more simple than it seems? See in this post how to create your first NuGet package. <!--more-->The idea of this post is to help you in creating yo<strong>ur first</strong> NuGet package. This means that we\'re not going deep into any of the aspects of the creation of packages. On the other hand, the official website<a href="https://docs.nuget.org/create/creating-and-publishing-a-package"> of NuGet has a detailed</a> documentation about creating packages, for when you are ready to deepen. Meanwhile, let\'s start with the basics. All of the examples from now on will use a hypothetical CPF validation library is made in c #, created by a team in a fictitious company named Fabrikam, you want to share this library with other internal teams within the same company. <h2>Basic concepts</h2> NuGet packages are a convenient mechanism for sharing software artifacts. Although optimized for share libraries .NET assemblies, they can be used for much more than apenas.net, being used to package virtually anything that needs to be versioned and distributed in convenient way. Want a sample? Did you know there are several cases of NuGet packages that contain only scripts PowerShell? Is a convenient way to package and redistribute scripts that are used, for example, during the build and deployment process of an application. Technically speaking, a package NuGet is just a ZIP file that follows a naming pattern and contains a metadata file describing the contents of that file. Means that, since following the appropriate conventions, we could create a NuGet package just by using a compression tool such as 7-Zip. Let\'s see now each of these three aspects: naming, metadata and content. <h3>NuGet package name</h3> NuGet packages should follow a Convention to be named. You should necessarily follow the same Convention for your package to be recognized by NuGet: <strong><code>&lt;Nome do="" pacote=""&gt;. &lt;Vers\xe3o semver=""&gt;. nupkg&lt;/Vers\xe3o&gt;&lt;/Nome&gt;</code></strong> In the package name, you can use letters, numbers and periods. A common strategy part avoid name collisions is to use your company name as a prefix in the name of the library, as we do with .NET assemblies. In our example, our package will be called F<strong>abrikam. ValidadorCPF</strong>. The extension of the file, in turn, should always be <strong><code>nupkg</code></strong>. Let\'s talk now about versioning. <h3>Package versioning</h3> The package versioning is a central aspect in NuGet. After all, one of the great benefits of using NuGet is able to manage the different dependencies for a project, updating them where desired or necessary. To do this, you do need to use a schema for description of the package version. The problem is a version number, it\'s something common in our day, is far from consistent. After all, if you get in a circle of friends and programmers submit a version number such as<strong> 1.0.3.25</strong>7 and ask what is the meaning of each of the segments (and under what circumstances they should be incremented) will probably hear very different explanations. In an attempt to create a consistent algorithm for definition of version numbers, was born the initiative of Versioning Semantics (S<em>emantic Versioning)</em>, which describes how to create a version identifier, which the meaning of each segment and in what circumstances increases them. The NuGet, fortunately, follows the pattern set in the web<a href="http://www.semver.org">site semver.</a>org, which is the official source of documentation for the Semantic Versioning. It is important that you familiarize yourself with this concept; take a break from reading this post, go to semver.org and then come back here. I hope;-). Returning to our example, chose decided my first package will be born with the 1.0 version. In this way, the full name of my package (now with the version number) is: <strong><code>Fabrikam. ValidadorCPF. nupkg 1.0.0.</code></strong> Simple, huh? Now let\'s talk about the metadata required to describe our package. <h3>Metadata-the manifest file</h3> When you access the dialog box from Visual Studio Packages management (or when browsing the site NuGet.org) may notice that a package NuGet contains several metadata that help describes it. Information such as name, author, description, dependencies ... Without it, other programmers would have trouble understanding so that your package serves. These metadata are part of a<strong> specification file NuGet</strong>-a manifest XML file, with a predetermined format and nuspec exte<strong>nsion</strong>. We need to create this file and embeds it in our package (IE, put it inside the zip file). <a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetDialog.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="NuGet dialog box in Visual Studio, showing the various NuGet package metadata: the ID (1), (2) description and other information such as version, authors, and site license (3) (click to enlarge)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetDialog_thumb.png" alt="NuGet dialog box in Visual Studio, showing the various NuGet package metadata: the ID (1), (2) description and other information such as version, authors, and site license project (3)" width="601" height="484" border="0" /></a> The full definition of the nuspec file format is ava<a href="https://docs.nuget.org/create/nuspec-reference">ilable on the official website of </a>NuGet, if you want to delve into later. Let\'s see now the basic elements for the creation of a manifesto to describe our CPF validation package: <pre class="brush: xml; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?&gt; &lt;package&gt;&lt;/package&gt; &lt;metadata&gt;&lt;/metadata&gt; &lt;id&gt;Fabrikam. ValidadorCPF&lt;/id&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0.0&lt;/version&gt; &lt;authors&gt;Fabrikam\'s shared services team&lt;/authors&gt; &lt;description&gt;This package provides CPF validation routines for .NET applications&lt;/description&gt; &lt;language&gt;en&lt;/language&gt; &lt;projectUrl&gt;http://intranet.fabrikam.com/componentes/Fabrikam.ValidadorCPF&lt;/projectUrl&gt; &lt;licenseUrl&gt;http://intranet.fabrikam.com/componentes/Fabrikam.ValidadorCPF/license.htm&lt;/licenseUrl&gt; </pre> <em>Example of the file ValidadorCPF. nuspec Fabrikam.</em> This is the typical NuGet package manifest. In it you see the elements that, minimally, need to be present in file to describe your nuspec package. The elements are self-explanatory, except perhaps the two URLs. The first, &lt;projectURL&gt;, indicates where a developer who want more information about your library can find a website with documentation.&lt;/projectURL&gt; Can be a wiki, a TFS team project, a repository from GitHub. Already &lt; licenseurl=""&gt; points to a document with the license of use of the component. This information is more important for publicly shared components, but sometimes even internal components may have different license models \u2013 especially when we have outsourced teams from different companies consuming our components. Where do I put the nuspec file? The best place to put it is in the project, next to the .csproj<code> file </code>of the library. The nuspec should be placed under version control, along with the rest of the library code. <h3>Contents \u2013 setting the files package</h3> Still in our archive nuspec, need now to list which files should be included in our package. To keep our simple example, will include only one file: <em>the ass</em>embly of our CPF validation library. Package contents NuGet is set from the element &lt;files&gt;.&lt;/files&gt; Take a look at how is our file, now changed to include our library and its documentation XML file (generated from the<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/b2s063f7(v=vs.140).aspx" target="_blank"> XML comments</a>): <pre class="brush: xml; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; highlight: [12,13,14,15]; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?&gt; &lt;package&gt;&lt;/package&gt; &lt;metadata&gt;&lt;/metadata&gt; &lt;id&gt;Fabrikam. ValidadorCPF&lt;/id&gt; &lt;version&gt;1.0.0&lt;/version&gt; &lt;authors&gt;Fabrikam\'s shared services team&lt;/authors&gt; &lt;description&gt;This package provides CPF validation routines for .NET applications&lt;/description&gt; &lt;language&gt;en&lt;/language&gt; &lt;projectUrl&gt;http://intranet.fabrikam.com/componentes/Fabrikam.ValidadorCPF&lt;/projectUrl&gt; &lt;licenseUrl&gt;http://intranet.fabrikam.com/componentes/Fabrikam.ValidadorCPF/license.htm&lt;/licenseUrl&gt; &lt;files&gt;&lt;/files&gt; &lt;file src="binReleaseFabrikam.ValidadorCPF.dll" target="lib"&gt;&lt;/file&gt; &lt;file src="binReleaseFabrikam.ValidadorCPF.xml" target="lib"&gt;&lt;/file&gt; </pre> Featured lines we can that our two files are obtained from the BinRelease folder of the project and copied to a folder named lib, through <strong>the</strong> target attribute of the element &lt;file&gt;.&lt;/file&gt; Incidentally, remember that we put in the same folder as the .csproj nuspec? This is one of the reasons: enable relative references. This lib f<strong>old</strong>er has a special meaning for the NuGet: Any assemblies found in this folder during installation of the package will be referenced in the target project. That is, if someone from our company add our package NuGet a .NET project any, our library (which was copied to the lib fol<strong>de</strong>r) will be automatically added to the project references. Exactly the behavior we want. Now it\'s time to see all that work. Though "theoretically" we can use 7-Zip, in practice have a e<strong>asie</strong>r way of creating our package! <h2>Generating the file. nupkg</h2> With the nuspec file created, everything is pretty easy. We will use the command line tool NuGet (nuget.exe; download instructions h<a href="https://docs.nuget.org/consume/installing-nuget" target="_blank">ere</a>). The first thing to do is compile your project in Release mode (because it is the setting that we\'re referencing the nuspec file for example). Then, open the command prompt and, from the folder where are the project files, run: <strong><code>nuget pack Fabrikam. ValidadorCPF. nuspec</code></strong> The result is your nupkg file, ready for use. <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-smile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile.png" alt="Alegre" /> Ready to test? Then open your Visual Studio and follow the steps below. <a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="Dialog box with the options of NuGet (click to enlarge)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb.png" alt="Dialog box with the options of NuGet" width="644" height="437" border="0" /></a> In Tools | Options, search for "nuget" (1). Then, select the opt<strong>ion Package So</strong>urces (2) and click the button to add a new NuGet package origin (3). Give a name to this new origin (4), enter the directory where we just generate the nupkg file (5) and then click Update (6) and OK. Finally, create a new .NET project and select the "Manage NuGet Packages ...". <a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image-1.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="New package being listed in Visual Studio (click to enlarge)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-1.png" alt="New package being listed in Visual Studio" width="644" height="434" border="0" /></a> NuGet window, select the source (1) we just created and see what happens! <h2>Distributing packages</h2> Obviously none of this makes sense if you can\'t share your packages with the other developers of the company. Soon comes the question: where to host my packages so that other developers have access? Well, that depends on if your package is public or private. <h3>Public packages</h3> Public packages (which can be freely used by developers inside and outside your company), the obvious choice is the <a href="http://www.nuget.org" target="_blank">nuget.org</a>. However, for being a repository accessible to the general public, is not the best place to publish test suites. While you are testing their packages, use the website service m<a href="http://www.myget.org" target="_blank">yget.org</a>. The free plan is sufficient for testing purposes. <h3>Private packages</h3> If your packages are only for internal use of your business, a public repository is obviously not a good option. There are a number of options to host repositories NuGet in private cloud or within your company: <ul> <li>Cloud ("NuGet-as-a-Service") <ul> <li><a href="https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/get-started/package/what-is-packaging" target="_blank">Visual Studio Team Services</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.myget.org/" target="_blank">MyGet.o</a>rg (only in paid <a href="https://www.myget.org/pricing" target="_blank">plans</a>)</li> <li><a href="https://www.appveyor.com/docs/nuget" target="_blank">AppVeyor</a></li> </ul> </li> <li>On-premises (internal server) <ul> <li><a href="https://docs.nuget.org/create/hosting-your-own-nuget-feeds#creating-local-feeds" target="_blank">Network fol</a>de<em>r (simple but inconvenient; you need to click on Update Options window "Package Sources" of Visual Studio for new packages. Not recommend</em>)</li> <li><a href="https://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.Server/" target="_blank">Nuget Serv</a>e<em>r (very rudimentary; has no Web interface. Not recommend</em>)</li> <li><a href="http://inedo.com/proget" target="_blank">Inedo ProGet</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.jfrog.com/artifactory/" target="_blank">Jfrog Artifactory</a></li> <li><a href="http://www.sonatype.org/nexus/" target="_blank">At Sonatype Nexus</a></li> </ul> </li> </ul> In most cases (with the exception of AppVeyor and network folders), you need to create an account. Once created, your account will contain information critical to the publishing process: y<strong>our API key</strong> (<em>API Key</em>). This key will be used by the comman<strong>d pu</strong>sh NuGet, responsible for publishing your package to your repository. The command is: <strong><code>nuget push-Source &lt;URL do="" servidor="" de="" destino=""&gt;-ApiKey &lt;sua chave="" de="" api=""&gt;&lt;/sua&gt; &lt;/URL&gt;</code></strong> Developers who are using their packages need to add your repository to Visual Studio. The process is identical to that we used above to add the test folder; the difference is that instead of pointing to a local directory on the computer, they would add the URL of your <em>feed</em> NuGet. Each repository NuGet represents your feed URLs differently. Check the documentation of your chosen store to know what URL should be added to the Visual Studio. <h2>Conclusion</h2> Phew! I know it\'s a lot for a post, but I think with that you can start building your first packages. There is still much more to be explored in this matter. Stay tuned for the next posts on NuGet! Oh, leave an exercise to you, dear reader: If you notice well, you\'ll see that many of the metadata included in our nuspec file typically are present also in our .NET assembly, through the various assembly metadata attributes. Information such as name, description, author, version, and other likely duplicates. Wouldn\'t it be a lot cooler if instead of entering this information on the nuspec file, we could instruct the NuGet to seek it in our design in packaging time? So we could keep this data in one place: in the .NET project! The exercise, therefore, is: How do the NuGet reuse metadata for assembly that we have in our project, so you don\'t need to retype the same data on the nuspec file? Good exercise! Oh, and be sure to share your opinion in the comments! A hug, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetPackage_thumb.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/NugetDialog_thumb.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-1.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/en/2016/03/02/learn-how-to-create-your-first-nuget-package/', 'date': u'2016-03-02 11:00:00', 'slug': u'learn-how-to-create-your-first-nuget-package', 'title': u'Learn how to create your first NuGet package', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'ALM', u'Development'], u'post_translations': [u'7b373d44-1083-4b3e-91a1-a7fb9c948eb8'], u'language': [u'English']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11361', 'type': u'post'}

Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-1.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'Controle de acesso a bancos de dados \xe9 algo que perturba a vida de desenvolvedores, IT Pros e DBAs desde\u2026 Bem, desde sempre! Sabe aquele est\xf3ria de <em>connection string</em> com usu\xe1rio e senha rolando para l\xe1 e para c\xe1? Quem nunca, n\xe9? <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-smile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png" alt="Alegre" /> Al\xe9m dos problemas \xf3bvios com isso \u2013 acesso n\xe3o-autorizado a dados que muitas vezes s\xe3o confidenciais, h\xe1 um outro agravante: os logins no SQL Server acontecem sempre no n\xedvel do servidor. Em outras palavras, h\xe1 sempre o risco de um usu\xe1rio malicioso fazer o que n\xe3o deve no banco de dados <code>master</code> do SQL Server. Sabia que o SQL Server 2012 introduziu uma nova funcionalidade que reduz \u2013 e muito \u2013 esse risco? Venha conhecer os novos <strong>usu\xe1rios contidos</strong> (<em>contained users</em>). <!--more--> Historicamente, o processo de cria\xe7\xe3o de usu\xe1rios no SQL Server sempre foi feito em duas etapas. Na primeira criamos um <strong>login</strong> para que o usu\xe1rio possa se conectar ao servidor: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">CREATE LOGIN nome_do_usu\xe1rio WITH PASSWORD = \'senha_do_usu\xe1rio\'</pre> Esse login \xe9 criado no banco de dados <code>master</code>, que cont\xe9m todas as informa\xe7\xf5es de sistema do SQL Server (e. por isso mesmo, \xe9 extremamente sens\xedvel). A seguir, criamos um <strong>user</strong> em cada um dos bancos de dados a que esse login deve ter acesso: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">USE DATABASE foo GO CREATE nome_do_usu\xe1rio FOR LOGIN \'nome_do_usu\xe1rio\' </pre> O problema todo \xe9 a cria\xe7\xe3o do login no banco de dados <code>master</code>. Se, por acaso, o <em>lockdown</em> da conta n\xe3o for adequadamente feito, no caso de uma invas\xe3o (atrav\xe9s de SQL Injection, por exemplo), o invasor teria acesso ao banco de dados <code>master</code> e, de l\xe1, fazer enormes estragos (como o bom e velho DROP TABLE que acompanha praticamente todo ataque de SQL Injection). <h2>Habilitando o uso de usu\xe1rios contidos</h2> A mudan\xe7a introduzida no SQL Server 2012 \xe9 a de conter (limitar) um usu\xe1rio a um \xfanico banco de dados. Ou seja, agora podemos criar um user sem um login associado. Dessa forma, esse usu\xe1rio n\xe3o tem acesso ao <code>master</code>, mas apenas ao banco de dados designado. No caso de uma invas\xe3o, os danos podem ser contidos \u2013 na pior das hip\xf3teses \u2013 a apenas o banco de dados que est\xe1 sendo acessado. Para usar usu\xe1rios contidos \xe9 preciso configurar seu ambiente. Esse processo varia dependendo do qu\xea voc\xea est\xe1 usando \u2013 SQL Server (<em>on-premises</em>) ou SQL Azure (nuvem). <h3>SQL Server (on-premises)</h3> Se voc\xea usa um SQL Server <em>on-premises</em>, ent\xe3o \xe9 necess\xe1rio ter a vers\xe3o 2012 ou superior. Al\xe9m disso, \xe9 necess\xe1rio ativar o recurso de usu\xe1rios contidos: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">sp_configure \'contained database authentication\', 1; GO RECONFIGURE; GO</pre> <h3>SQL Azure (nuvem)</h3> J\xe1 no SQL Azure, \xe9 preciso que seu servidor esteja em modo de compatibilidade V12. Acesse o Portal do Azure, navegue at\xe9 seu servidor e selecione a op\xe7\xe3o <strong>Latest SQL Database Update</strong> (1). <a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image-2.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="Op\xe7\xe3o no Portal do Azure para atualizar um servidor SQL Azure (clique para ampliar)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png" alt="Op\xe7\xe3o no Portal do Azure para atualizar um servidor SQL Azure" width="644" height="467" border="0" /></a> Fa\xe7a o update (se necess\xe1rio) e o recurso de <em>contained users</em> estar\xe1 ativado automaticamente. <h2>Utilizando usu\xe1rios contidos</h2> Uma vez que o recurso esteja dispon\xedvel, use o comando CREATE USER para criar seus usu\xe1rios contidos: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">USE DATABASE foo GO CREATE USER nome_do_usu\xe1rio WITH PASSWORD = \'senha_do_usu\xe1rio\'; GO</pre> Agora, basta alterar suas <em>connection strings</em> para usar esse usu\xe1rio. Como o usu\xe1rio existe apenas no contexto do banco de dados, n\xe3o se esque\xe7a de informar o banco correto no instante da conex\xe3o: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">Server=nome_do_servidor; Database=nome_do_banco; User ID=nome_do_usu\xe1rio; Password=senha_do_usu\xe1rio</pre> <h2>Para saber mais</h2> <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff929188" target="_blank">Contained Database Users - Making Your Database Portable</a> <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff929237" target="_blank">contained database authentication Server Configuration Option</a> &nbsp; Um abra\xe7o, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/2016/03/03/aumente-a-segurana-de-seu-sql-server-com-usurios-contidos/', 'date': u'2016-03-03 19:35:19', 'slug': u'aumente-a-segurana-de-seu-sql-server-com-usurios-contidos', 'title': u'Aumente a seguran\xe7a de seu SQL Server com usu\xe1rios contidos', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'ALM', u'Desenvolvimento'], u'post_translations': [u'11908fcb-9a2a-431a-b8fe-4a581dde5bd5'], u'language': [u'Portugu\xeas'], u'post_tag': [u'Azure', u'SQL Azure', u'SQL Server']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11441', 'type': u'post'}
build/jekyll/www.tshooter.com.br/_posts/2016-03/aumente-a-segurana-de-seu-sql-server-com-usurios-contidos/2016-03-03-Post.md
URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'<em>(This post is machine-translated. A proper translation is in the works)</em> Control of access to databases is something that disturbs the life of developers, IT Pros and DBAs. Well, since ever! You know the story of<em> connection strin</em>g with user and password rolling to and fro? Who never, huh? <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-smile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png" alt="Alegre" /> Besides the obvious problems with this \u2014 unauthorized access to data that are often confidential, there is another aggravating factor: the logins in SQL Server always happen at the server level. In other words, there is always the risk of a malicious user to do what must master data<code>base </code>of SQL Server. Did you know that SQL Server 2012 has introduced a new feature that reduces \u2013 and \u2013 that risk? Come meet new u<strong>sers contained </strong>(c<em>ontained users</em>). <!--more--> Historically, the process of creating users in SQL Server has always been done in two steps. At first we create a<strong> logi</strong>n so that the user can connect to the server: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">CREATE LOGIN username WITH PASSWORD = \' userpassword \'</pre> This login is created in the master da<code>tabase</code>, which contains all of the SQL Server system information (and. It is therefore extremely sensitive). Next, create a use<strong>r in</strong> each of the databases that this login should have access: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">USE DATABASE foo GO CREATE username FOR LOGIN \' username \' </pre> The whole problem is the creation of the login in the master d<code>atabas</code>e. If, by chance, t<em>he lockd</em>own of the account is not properly done, in the case of an invasion (via SQL Injection, for example), the attacker would have access to the mas<code>ter da</code>tabase and from there make huge damage (like the good old DROP TABLE that accompanies virtually any SQL Injection attack). <h2>Enabling the use of users contained</h2> The change introduced in SQL Server 2012 is to contain (limit) a user to a single database. In other words, we can now create a user without a login associated with it. Thus, this user does not have access to th<code>e mast</code>er, but only to the designated database. In the case of an invasion, the damage can be contained \u2013 at worst \u2013 only the database that is being accessed. To use users contained you must configure your environment. This process varies depending on what you are using \u2013 SQL Server (<em>on-premises</em>) or SQL Azure (cloud). <h3>SQL Server (on-premises)</h3> If you use a SQL Server on<em>-premises, s</em>o it is necessary to have the 2012 version or higher. In addition, it is necessary to activate the feature of users contained: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">sp_configure \' contained database authentication \', 1; GO RECONFIGURE; GO</pre> <h3>SQL Azure (cloud)</h3> Already in SQL Azure, your server is in compatibility mode V12. Visit the Azure Portal, navigate to your server and select the La<strong>test SQL Database Update</strong> (1). <a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image-2.png"><img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="Option in the Azure Portal to update a SQL Server Azure (click to enlarge)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png" alt="Option in the Azure Portal to update a SQL Server Azure" width="644" height="467" border="0" /></a> Do the update (if necessary) and the containe<em>d resource user</em>s will be enabled automatically. <h2>Using users contained</h2> Once the resource is available, use the command CREATE USER to create its users contained: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">USE DATABASE foo GO CREATE USER username WITH PASSWORD = \' userpassword \'; GO</pre> Now, just change your <em>connection stri</em>ngs to use that user. As the user exists only in the context of the database, don\'t forget to inform the Bank right in the moment of the connection: <pre class="brush: sql; auto-links: true; collapse: false; first-line: 1; gutter: true; html-script: false; light: false; ruler: false; smart-tabs: true; tab-size: 4; toolbar: true;">Server = servername; Database = db_name; User ID = username; Password = userPassword</pre> <h2>To find out more</h2> <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff929188" target="_blank">Contained Database Users-Making Your Database Portable</a> <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff929237" target="_blank">contained database authentication Server Configuration Option</a> A hug, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/en/2016/03/03/increase-the-security-of-your-sql-server-with-users-contained/', 'date': u'2016-03-03 19:35:19', 'slug': u'increase-the-security-of-your-sql-server-with-users-contained', 'title': u'Increase the security of your SQL Server with Contained Users', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'Development'], u'post_translations': [u'11908fcb-9a2a-431a-b8fe-4a581dde5bd5'], u'language': [u'English']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11491', 'type': u'post'}
build/jekyll/www.tshooter.com.br/_posts/2016-03/increase-the-security-of-your-sql-server-with-users-contained/2016-03-03-Post.md
URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-1.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image_thumb-2.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'H\xe1 um ano atr\xe1s escrevi um post com <a href="/2015/03/13/oito-razes-para-preferir-tfvc-ao-invs-de-git/" target="_blank">oito raz\xf5es para usar o TFVC ao inv\xe9s do Git</a> no TFS. \xc0 \xe9poca, disse que escreveria um post complementar com os argumentos para dar prefer\xeancia ao Git ao inv\xe9s do TFVC. Bem, demorou mas chegou a hora. Eis aqui oito raz\xf5es para preferir o uso de Git ao inv\xe9s de TFVC num <em>team project</em> do TFS ou do VSTS. <!--more--> Devo dizer que queria muito ir direto ao ponto, mas infelizmente n\xe3o posso. Isso porque, primeiramente, tenho que fazer uma admiss\xe3o p\xfablica. <h2>Git \xe9 melhor que o TFVC. E ponto.</h2> Muita gente perdeu a cabe\xe7a quando, no \u201cpost-irm\xe3o\u201d deste aqui, brinquei que o TFVC era melhor que o Git. Definitivamente a internet tem se tornado cada vez mais um lugar de justiceiros ranzinzas. Bem, para trazer um pouco de felicidade a essa horda de <em>grumpies</em>, est\xe1 devidamente registrado neste post que o Git \xe9 melhor que o TFVC. Ah, uma coisa importante a frisar: a ideia desses posts nunca foi comparar o Git e o TFVC de maneira gen\xe9rica, fora de um contexto espec\xedfico. Pelo contr\xe1rio, a ideia era que o contexto fosse <strong>bem</strong> espec\xedfico: <blockquote>Para um usu\xe1rio de <strong>TFS</strong> que v\xe1 criar um novo reposit\xf3rio de controle de vers\xe3o, qual op\xe7\xe3o escolher? TFVC ou Git?</blockquote> Viu? A compara\xe7\xe3o \xe9 \xfanica e exclusivamente dentro do contexto de <strong>usu\xe1rios do TFS/VSTS</strong>. Se voc\xea n\xe3o usa nenhum dos dois, ent\xe3o talvez alguns dos pontos discutidos neste post n\xe3o sejam t\xe3o relevantes. Ainda assim, seus coment\xe1rios ser\xe3o bem-vindos! Com isso tudo fora do caminho, acho que finalmente estou livre para falar do que interessa\u2026 <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-winkingsmile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png" alt="Smiley piscando" /> Eis os oito motivos para preferir o Git ao TFVC como reposit\xf3rio de controle de vers\xe3o no TFS/VSTS: <h3>Padr\xe3o <em>de facto</em> para controle de vers\xe3o</h3> A guerra dos reposit\xf3rios de controle de vers\xe3o acabou e o Git venceu. Simples assim. \xc9 claro que os outros v\xe3o continuar por a\xed por muito tempo; Subversion, Mercurial, CVS, TFVC, ClearCase, RTC Streams, Perforce e at\xe9 mesmo SourceSafe (!) ainda estar\xe3o por a\xed por uns bons anos. Mas o futuro chegou e ele se chama Git. Dessa forma, se voc\xea n\xe3o tem nenhum dos motivos citados no post anterior para ficar com o TFVC, este por si s\xf3 talvez j\xe1 seja motivo suficiente. Adotar o Git significa dar uma garantia de longevidade para seu projeto que o TFVC simplesmente n\xe3o tem como oferecer. Ah, se voc\xea \xe9 um desenvolvedor e ainda n\xe3o conhece Git, #ficaadica: voc\xea est\xe1 ficando obsoleto mais r\xe1pido do que voc\xea imagina\u2026 <h3><em>Lingua franca</em> do mundo open-source</h3> O Git nasceu com uma finalidade bem espec\xedfica: servir como solu\xe7\xe3o de controle de vers\xe3o para ser usada pelos desenvolvedores do Kernel do Linux \u2013 ali\xe1s, o criador do Git \xe9 o pr\xf3prio Linus Torvalds. Por\xe9m a solu\xe7\xe3o ficou t\xe3o bacana e flex\xedvel que acabou sendo adotada por outros projetos open-source. Essa ado\xe7\xe3o por outros projetos OSS come\xe7ou de maneira t\xedmida mas com o tempo foram substituindo outras op\xe7\xf5es open-source comumente usadas \u2013 Subversion em especial. O grande catalisador da ado\xe7\xe3o do Git como o formato padr\xe3o de reposit\xf3rio de projetos OSS, entretanto, foi o <a href="http://www.github.com" target="_blank">GitHub</a>. O conceito de \u201crede social para desenvolvedores\u201d, com a hospedagem gratuita de c\xf3digo-fonte para projetos open-source, n\xe3o era exatamente nova. <a href="http://www.sourceforge.net" target="_blank">SourceForge</a> j\xe1 existia e estava bem estabelecido quando o GitHub surgiu. Por\xe9m a experi\xeancia de usu\xe1rio do GitHub superou em muito a oferecida pelo SourceForge e outros sites equivalentes da \xe9poca. N\xe3o demorou muito para ele destronar todos eles (incluindo o tamb\xe9m malfadado <a href="http://www.codeplex.com" target="_blank">CodePlex</a> da Microsoft). Eu arriscaria dizer que a maioria absoluta dos projetos open-source, hoje em dia, \xe9 hospedado no GitHub. E o que isso tem a ver com usu\xe1rios de TFS e VSTS? Bem, open-source \xe9 algo que sempre foi importante em todas as comunidades de desenvolvimento \u2013 mesmo as propriet\xe1rias, como era o caso do .NET at\xe9 h\xe1 pouco tempo atr\xe1s. Mas essa import\xe2ncia vem aumentando a cada dia; basta ver os movimentos todos da Microsoft na dire\xe7\xe3o da abertura do c\xf3digo de diversos de seus produtos, al\xe9m da integra\xe7\xe3o com solu\xe7\xf5es open-source. Seus times de desenvolvimento inevitavelmente ter\xe3o de interagir com projetos open-source mais cedo ou mais tarde. Dominar Git agora \u2013 usar Git no dia-a-dia \u2013 significa minimizar o atrito que eles sofrer\xe3o em suas primeiras incurs\xf5es por conceitos t\xedpicos de projetos open-source baseados em Git e hospedados no GitHub. Al\xe9m disso, novos desenvolvedores j\xe1 estar\xe3o provavelmente familiarizados com o Git; oferecer um reposit\xf3rio corporativo baseado em Git diminui o tempo que esse dev leva para se integrar ao seu time, comparado com algu\xe9m que precisaria se acostumar com TFVC. <h3>Distribu\xeddo e descentralizado</h3> Quem trabalha com controles de vers\xe3o centralizados \u2013 como \xe9 o caso do TFVC \u2013 normalmente morrem de medo de uma queda de rede/internet. Isso porque, se ficarem desconectados, n\xe3o conseguir\xe3o mais versionar seu c\xf3digo-fonte. Um DVCS (<em>distributed version control system</em>), por outro lado, n\xe3o sofre desse mal. Desenhado explicitamente para suportar cen\xe1rios desconectados, o Git permite que desenvolvedores fa\xe7am uma c\xf3pia (\u201cclone\u201d) do reposit\xf3rio de controle de vers\xe3o em suas m\xe1quinas individuais. Assim, os commits podem ser feitos em seu pr\xf3prio computador, sem depender de acesso a um banco de dados centralizado. Uma vez que o conjunto de altera\xe7\xf5es feitas pelo desenvolvedor esteja pronto para ser integrado ao reposit\xf3rio central, ele \u201cempurra\u201d (\u201c<em>push</em>\u201d) suas altera\xe7\xf5es. Na Lambda3, por exemplo, isso \xe9 particularmente \xfatil. Nossos times de desenvolvimento que atendem a clientes remotos n\xe3o precisam de uma conex\xe3o online o tempo todo com o TFS do cliente para poderem trabalhar. Eles clonam o reposit\xf3rio, fazer seu trabalho desconectados e, assim que estiverem prontos, integram seu trabalho com o resto do time fazendo o <em>push</em> para o TFS do cliente. Ou seja, mesmo que a VPN tenha ficado indispon\xedvel por um tempo, eles n\xe3o deixaram de trabalhar. <h3>Commits frequentes</h3> A conveni\xeancia de trabalhar desconectado e de entregar o c\xf3digo apenas quando pronto (testado etc.) permitiu que desenvolvedores que utilizam Git acabassem criando um h\xe1bito bastante salutar: Fazer commits frequentes (\xe0s vezes na casa das dezenas de commits por dia), registrando pequenos incrementos de c\xf3digo. Dessa forma, revisar suas altera\xe7\xf5es (e voltar atr\xe1s, se necess\xe1rio) se torna muito mais f\xe1cil. Al\xe9m disso, recursos como <strong>amend</strong> (a possibilidade de corrigir o \xfaltimo commit, alterando seu conte\xfado), <strong>rebase</strong> (reescrita do hist\xf3rico de commits) e <strong>squash</strong> (a combina\xe7\xe3o de diversos commits em um s\xf3) diminuem em muito o medo de se criar v\xe1rios commits, pois o desenvolvedor tem a liberdade de alterar e ajustar esses commits \xe0 vontade, deixando-os \u201credondinhos\u201d para o momento da integra\xe7\xe3o. <h3>Branching e merging mais simples e eficientes</h3> Quem \xe9 que n\xe3o tem pavor de <em>merges</em>? Garanto a voc\xea que todo usu\xe1rio de TFVC tem <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-smile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png" alt="Alegre" />. Esse \xe9, a meu ver, um dos maiores benef\xedcios que o Git traz em compara\xe7\xe3o com o TFVC: seu algoritmo de branching e merging \xe9 <strong>muito</strong> mais eficiente que o TFVC, reduzindo consideravelmente a quantidade de conflitos que no TFVC teriam de ser resolvidos manualmente. <h3>Pull requests</h3> Outra funcionalidade muito bacana do Git quando usado dentro do TFS/VSTS, o <em>pull request</em> corresponde, de certa maneira, ao <em>code review</em> do TFVC. \xc9 um dos mecanismos mais bacanas para ajudar os times a melhorar a qualidade do seu c\xf3digo, pois estimula o <em>peer review</em>. Na Lambda3, por exemplo, h\xe1 um acordo na maioria dos projetos de desenvolvimento: nenhum desenvolvedor faz <em>push</em> direto para o branch master. Integra\xe7\xf5es devem acontecer sempre atrav\xe9s de pull requests. Dessa forma, outros desenvolvedores do time t\xeam a oportunidade de revisar o c\xf3digo antes de integra-lo, minimizando o risco de integrar c\xf3digo com problemas. Al\xe9m disso, a funcionalidade de pull requests oferece v\xe1rias conveni\xeancias como a exibi\xe7\xe3o do status do \xfaltimo build de CI (build quebrado, pull request rejeitado), o hist\xf3rico de discuss\xf5es (com as dicas de corre\xe7\xf5es/melhorias de c\xf3digo) e o merge autom\xe1tico (sempre que poss\xedvel, claro). <h3>Cross-platform</h3> Muitas pessoas ainda veem o TFS/VSTS como uma solu\xe7\xe3o de controle de projetos .NET, mesmo que h\xe1 anos isso n\xe3o seja verdade. Por\xe9m, ainda que a Microsoft ofere\xe7a um <em>client </em>cross-platform para o TFVC (conhecido como <a href="https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/products/team-explorer-everywhere-vs.aspx" target="_blank">Team Explorer Everywhere</a>) ele tem suas limita\xe7\xf5es. J\xe1 o Git, por outro lado, \xe9 suportado em praticamente todos os sistemas operacionais e est\xe1 integrado \xe0 maioria dos IDEs e editores de texto para programadores \u2013 tem at\xe9 mesmo <a href="https://github.com/creationix/js-git" target="_blank">Git escrito em Javascript</a>! Ao adotar o Git no TFS/VSTS, voc\xea facilita a vida dos seus times que trabalham em plataformas n\xe3o-Microsoft, como por exemplo os desenvolvedores de iOS e Android. <h3>Git Flow</h3> Uma outra queixa comum de usu\xe1rios de TFVC \xe9 \u201c<em>como devo estruturar meu modelo de branches?</em>\u201d Na falta de um modelo padronizado e consistente, cada time \u201cinventa\u201d um modelo diferente de trabalho que muitas vezes mais atrapalha do que ajuda. J\xe1 com o Git, voc\xea n\xe3o precisa partir do zero. Ao inv\xe9s disso, pode usar o processo conhecido como \u201c<a href="http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/" target="_blank">Git Flow</a>\u201d \u2013 um processo simples, eficiente e bem documentado de gerenciamento de branches e de releases para Git. Como todo processo, h\xe1 os que gostam e os que desgostam. Avalie-o para ver se se adequa ao modelo de trabalho do seu time. Mas \xe9 melhor que \u201cinventar\u201d um modelo do zero, dentro de casa. Al\xe9m disso, s\xe3o grandes as chances de que novas contrata\xe7\xf5es em seu time conhe\xe7am o Git Flow, ajudando de novo a reduzir o atrito inicial do <em>onboarding</em> de um novo membro no time. <h2>O fim do \u201came-o ou deixe-o\u201d</h2> Ah, isso \xe9 muito legal: Recentemente a escolha por Git ou TFVC deixou de ser algo dr\xe1stico, do tipo \u201cat\xe9 que a morte os separe\u201d. Antigamente, ao criar um <em>team project</em> no TFS/VSTS voc\xea escolhia um formato de reposit\xf3rio de controle de vers\xe3o e ficava preso a ele para o resto da vida daquele projeto. Agora, \xe9 poss\xedvel hospedar reposit\xf3rios Git e TFVC <strong>no mesmo <em>team project</em>.</strong> Isso oferece mais flexibilidade aos times, que podem escolher o formato de reposit\xf3rio que melhor lhes aprouver. &nbsp; O que achou do post? N\xe3o deixe de comentar! &nbsp; &nbsp; Um abra\xe7o, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/2016/03/07/oito-razes-para-preferir-git-ao-invs-de-tfvc/', 'date': u'2016-03-07 23:03:42', 'slug': u'oito-razes-para-preferir-git-ao-invs-de-tfvc', 'title': u'Oito raz\xf5es para preferir Git ao inv\xe9s de TFVC', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'ALM'], u'post_translations': [u'c71b3dd1-7c71-466d-ad81-589d2fee1a1f'], u'language': [u'Portugu\xeas'], u'post_tag': [u'Git', u'GitHub', u'TFS', u'VSTS']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11621', 'type': u'post'}
build/jekyll/www.tshooter.com.br/_posts/2016-03/oito-razes-para-preferir-git-ao-invs-de-tfvc/2016-03-07-Post.md
URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'A year ago I wrote a post with ei<a href="/2015/03/13/oito-razes-para-preferir-tfvc-ao-invs-de-git/" target="_blank">ght reasons to use the TFVC instead of Git</a> in TFS. At the time, said he would write a companion post with arguments to give preference to Git instead of TFVC. Well, it took but it was time. Here are eight reasons to prefer using Git instead of TFVC a <em>TFS team pr</em>oject or of VSTS. <!--more--> I must say that I really wanted to get to the point, but unfortunately I can&#39;t. This is because, first, I have to make a public admission. <h2>Git is better than the TFVC. And point.</h2> A lot of people lost his head when, in the &quot;post-brother&quot; this here, joked that the TFVC was better than Git. The internet has become increasingly a place of vigilantes sourpusses. Well, to bring a little happiness to this horde of gr<em>umpies, </em>is properly registered in this post that Git is better than the TFVC. Oh, one important thing to point out: the idea of these posts was never compare the Git and the TFVC generic way, out of a specific context. On the contrary, the idea was that the context wa<strong>s v</strong>ery specific: <blockquote>For a user to TFS<strong> t</strong>o go create a new version-control repository, which option to choose? TFVC or Git?</blockquote> Have you seen? The comparison is solely and exclusively within the con<strong>text of TFS/VSTS user</strong>s. If you don&#39;t use either of them, so maybe some of the points discussed in this post are not so relevant. Still, your comments are welcome! With all that out of the way, I think I&#39;m finally free to talk about what matters. <img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-winkingsmile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png" alt="Winking smiley" /> Here are eight reasons for preferring Git the TFVC version control repository in TFS/VSTS: <h3>De fac<em>to stand</em>ard for version control</h3> The war of version control repositories and Git won. Simple as that. Of course, the other will continue around for a long time; Subversion, Mercurial, CVS, TFVC, ClearCase, RTC Streams, Perforce and even SourceSafe (!) will still be around for a good few years. But the future is here and it&#39;s called Git. That way, if you don&#39;t have any of the reasons mentioned in the previous post to keep the TFVC, this in itself may already be reason enough. Adopt the Git means giving a guarantee of longevity to your project that TFVC simply do not have as offering. Oh, if you are a developer and don&#39;t know Git, #ficaadica: you are getting obsolete faster than you think. <h3><em>Lingua franca </em>of the world open-source</h3> Git was born with a very specific purpose: to serve as a version control solution for use by developers of the Linux Kernel \u2013 in fact, the creator of Git is Linus Torvalds himself. But the solution was so cool and flexible that ended up being adopted by other open source projects. This adoption by other OSS projects began to shy way but over time were replacing other commonly used open-source options \u2013 Subversion in particular. The major catalyst for the adoption of Git as the standard repository of OSS projects, however, was the <a href="http://www.github.com" target="_blank">GitHub</a>. The concept of &quot;social network for developers&quot;, with the free hosting of source code for open-source projects, isn&#39;t exactly new. <a href="http://www.sourceforge.net" target="_blank">SourceForge</a> already existed and was well established when the GitHub emerged. However the user experience of the GitHub overcame the offered by SourceForge and other equivalent sites of the time. It didn&#39;t take long for him to overthrow them all (including the ill-fated Co<a href="http://www.codeplex.com" target="_blank">dePlex f</a>rom Microsoft). I would hazard to say that the majority of open source projects, nowadays, is hosted on GitHub. And what does this have to do with users of TFS and VSTS? Well, open source is something that has always been important in all communities of development \u2013 even the owners, as was the case of .NET until a little while ago. But that importance is increasing with each passing day; just watch the movements all of Microsoft towards the opening of the code of several of their products, and the integration with open-source solutions. Their development teams inevitably must interact with other open source projects sooner or later. Mastering Git now \u2013 use Git on a daily basis \u2013 means minimizing the friction that they suffer in their first incursions by typical concepts of open-source projects based on Git and hosted on GitHub. In addition, new developers are probably familiar with Git; offer a corporate repository Git-based decreases the time that dev does it take to integrate to your team, compared with someone who would need to get used to TFVC. <h3>Distributed and decentralized</h3> Who works with version controls centered-as is the case with the TFVC \u2013 usually die of fright from a fall of network/internet. This is because, if you get disconnected, they can&#39;t get more version source code. A DVCS (di<em>stributed version control system), on th</em>e other hand, does not suffer from this badly. Designed explicitly to support disconnected scenarios, Git allows developers to make a copy (&quot;clone&quot;) of the version control repository on their individual machines. Thus, the commits can be made on your own computer, without relying on access to a centralized database. Once the set of changes made by the developer is ready to be integrated into the central repository, he &quot;push&quot; (&quot;<em>push</em>&quot;) your changes. On Lambda3, for example, that is particularly useful. Our development teams that serve remote clients do not require an online connection with the TFS client for to work. They clone the repository, do your work disconnected and, once they&#39;re ready, they integrate their work with the rest of the tea<em>m do</em>ing the push for TFS. In other words, even if the VPN was unavailable for a while, they have not stopped working. <h3>Frequent commits</h3> The convenience to work disconnected and deliver the code only when ready (tested etc.) allowed developers to use Git to end creating a very healthy habit: Do frequent commits (sometimes in the dozens of commits per day), with small amounts of code. Therefore, review your changes (and back, if necessary) becomes much easier. In addition, features su<strong>ch as</strong> amend (the possibility of correcting the last commit, changing its <strong>conten</strong>ts), rebase (rewrite of history of co<strong>mmits)</strong> and squash (a combination of several commits into one) decrease the fear to create multiple commits, because the developer is free to change and adjust those commits at will, leaving them &quot;bubble&quot; to the time of integration. <h3>Branching and merging more simple and efficient</h3> Who doesn&#39;t have a dread o<em>f merg</em>es? I assure you that every user of TFVC has<img class="wlEmoticon wlEmoticon-smile" style="border-style: none;" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png" alt="Alegre" />. This is, in my view, one of the greatest benefits that Git brings compared to the TFVC: your branching and merging algorith<strong>m is </strong>much more efficient than the TFVC, considerably reducing the amount of conflicts that in TFVC would have to be resolved manually. <h3>Pull requests</h3> Another very cool feature of Git when used inside the TFS/VSTS, th<em>e pull req</em>uest corresponds somehow to cod<em>e review t</em>he TFVC. Is one of the coolest mechanisms to help teams improve the quality of your code, because it stimulates the <em>peer review</em>. On Lambda3, for example, there is an agreement in most development projects: any developer makes push <em>stra</em>ight into the master branch. Integrations should happen via pull requests. That way, other developers on the team have the opportunity to review the code before integrating it, minimizing the risk of integrating code with problems. In addition, the functionality of pull requests offers several conveniences such as the display of the status of the last build of CI (build broken, pull request rejected), the history of discussions (with the tips of fixes/improvements) and merge (if possible of course). <h3>Cross-platform</h3> Many people still see TFS/VSTS as a .NET project control solution, even in years that&#39;s not true. However, even though Microsoft offers <em>a cros</em>s-platform client to the TFVC (known as T<a href="https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/products/team-explorer-everywhere-vs.aspx" target="_blank">eam Explorer Everywhere</a>) it has its limitations. Already Git, on the other hand, is supported in virtually all operating systems and is integrated to most IDEs and text editors for programmers \u2013 even Gi<a href="https://github.com/creationix/js-git" target="_blank">t written in Javascrip</a>t. By adopting the Git in TFS/VSTS, you make life easier for your teams who work on non-Microsoft platforms, such as iOS and Android developers. <h3>Git Flow</h3> Another common complaint from TFVC users is<em> &quot;How should I structure my blank template</em>?&quot; In the absence of a standardized and consistent model, each time &quot;invents&quot; a different model of work that often more hindrance than help. With Git, you do not need from scratch. Instead, you can use the process known as &quot;Gi<a href="http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/" target="_blank">t Flow&quot;</a> \u2013 a simple process, efficient and well-documented blank and management of releases to Git. Like any process, there are those who love and those who dislike. Evaluate it to see if it fits your team work model. But it&#39;s better than &quot;inventing&quot; a template from scratch, inside the House. In addition, the chances are great that new hires in your team meet Git Flow, helping again to reduce the initial onboarding fri<em>ction of </em>a new Member on the team. <h2>The end of &quot;love it or leave it&quot;</h2> Oh, this is really cool: recently the choice by Git or TFVC ceased to be something drastic, like &quot;till death do us part&quot;. In the old days, when you<em> create a te</em>am project in TFS/VSTS you choose a format of version control repository and was stuck with him for the rest of the life of that project. Now, it is possible to host Git repos and TFVC in <strong>the same <em>team project</em>.</strong> This provides more flexibility at times, you can choose the format of the repository that best they see fit. What did you think of the post? Be sure to comment! A hug, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/en/2016/03/07/eight-reasons-to-prefer-git-to-invs-tfvc/', 'date': u'2016-03-07 23:03:42', 'slug': u'eight-reasons-to-prefer-git-to-invs-tfvc', 'title': u'Eight reasons for preferring Git instead of TFVC', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'ALM'], u'post_translations': [u'c71b3dd1-7c71-466d-ad81-589d2fee1a1f'], u'language': [u'English']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11671', 'type': u'post'}

Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-winkingsmile.png... URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/wlEmoticon-smile-2.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'<img style="background-image: none; float: none; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; margin-left: auto; display: block; padding-right: 0px; margin-right: auto; border-width: 0px;" title="Licensing/Legal" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image-1.png" alt="Licensing/Legal" width="420" height="319" border="0" /> <em>(This post is machine-translated. A proper translation is in the works)</em> OK, I understand that in spite o<a href="http://www.tshooter.com.br/2016/02/15/sim-eu-deixei-de-usar-o-tfs-e-acho-que-voce-tambem-deveria/" target="_blank">f everything I mentioned in my post about TFS an</a>d VSTS you can have their reasons for wanting to use TF<em>S on-premise</em>s. When a company decides to use the TFS and prepares to do the installation, discovers that one of the prerequisites of the installation is SQL Server. This is where the question arises<em>: "How do I properly the SQL Server that will be used by TFS?"</em> The answer is so complicated but, like everything that involves licensing, requires care and attention. Here are the answers to some of the most frequently asked questions that we have made on this subject. <!--more--> <h2>I need pay for SQL Server?</h2> Usually not. TFS includes a SQL Server Standard license that can be us<strong>ed only for use of own TFS</strong>. In other words, there can be no other use \u2013 or database, or anything \u2013 other than of domestic own TFS. <h2>Where the SQL Server TFS media?</h2> Depends on how you obtained your license of the TFS: via "box", through a volume license or through an MSDN Subscription: <ol> <li><strong>"Box" (reta<em>il): w</em>h</strong>en you purchase a retail version (<em>the "b</em>ox", with physical media and all), receives two DVDs \u2013 one of the TFS, another SQL Server. In this case it\'s easy \u2013 just use this SQL Server media;</li> <li><strong>Volume license:</strong> this scenario applies to those customers who purchased a license for TFS through a volume contract as Open or Enterprise Agreement (EA). In this case, both the TFS as SQL Server Standard can be downloaded from the website<a href="https://www.microsoft.com/Licensing/servicecenter/default.aspx" target="_blank"> VLS</a>C;</li> <li><strong>MSDN subscripti</strong>on: This is the most common way \u2013 and cheaper \u2013 to obtain a license from the TFS. If you have a Visual Studio with an MSDN Subscription, you can download both the TFS as SQL Server from MS<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/subscriptions/securedownloads/default.aspx" target="_blank">DN subscribers</a>. <strong>IMPORTANT</strong>: you <strong>shoul</strong>d always download SQL Server Standard from MSDN subscribers, even if you have SQL Server licenses available on the VLSC. Otherwise, you\'re getting the wrong version and will not be properly licensed.</li> </ol> <h2>Can I install a <em>dual-server</em>?</h2> You can install the TFS and SQL Server on separate servers, without paying for it, only if you have more than one license of TFS. The most common is: you have several licenses of Visual Studio with MSDN on your team. Each of these licenses entitles you to TFS. In this case, separate two licenses; each of these licenses a server (TFS on the other hand, SQL Server Standard on the other side). <h2>Can I use the Enterprise version?</h2> TFS includes as free version only SQL Server Standard. If you prefer to use the SQL Server Enterprise, you must license it separately. <h2>Can I use the latest version of SQL Server?</h2> Of grace. You can only use the version that is explicitly mentioned on Vis<a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=13350" target="_blank">ual Studio Licensing White Paper</a>. Therefore, if this document is saying (for example) that TFS is accompanied by SQL Server 2014, then it is not allowed to install the SQL Server 2016. The document is updated frequently; in a future update of the<em> white pap</em>er version is updated and from here you can update your SQL Server. <h2>Where can I get more details?</h2> The official source of information is<a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=13350" target="_blank"> the Visual Studio Licensing White Pape</a>r. He will always have the last word with regard to licensing of Visual Studio and TFS. &nbsp; A hug, Igor', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image-1.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/en/2016/03/04/how-to-properly-license-sql-server-for-tfs-use/', 'date': u'2016-03-04 18:52:50', 'slug': u'how-to-properly-license-sql-server-for-tfs-use', 'title': u'How to properly license SQL Server for TFS use', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'ALM'], u'post_translations': [u'858c19c3-192e-4b1d-a6d1-015ba5c7e3f0'], u'language': [u'English'], u'post_tag': [u'TFS']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11711', 'type': u'post'}

URL Parse: https|www.tshooter.com.br|/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image-1.png|||
Downloading https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image-1.png....{'status': u'publish', 'body': u'<p>A Microsoft oferece dois servi\xe7os de armazenamento de arquivos em nuvem \u2013 OneDrive (tamb\xe9m chamado de OneDrive Pessoal) e OneDrive for Business. Apesar do nome parecido, foram por muito tempo duas coisas completamente diferentes.</p> <p>Usu\xe1rios dom\xe9sticos tipicamente utilizam o <a href="https://onedrive.live.com/about/pt-br/" target="_blank">OneDrive</a>, ao passo que aqueles que usam o Office 365 em suas empresas t\xeam tamb\xe9m o <a href="https://onedrive.live.com/about/pt-BR/business/" target="_blank">OneDrive for Business</a> (OD4B) \xe0 disposi\xe7\xe3o. O curioso \u2013 e vejo isso acontecer o tempo todo, tanto na Lambda3 quanto em clientes \u2013 \xe9 que muitos usu\xe1rios do Office 365 nem sequer sabem que o OneDrive for Business existe. E quando sabem de sua exist\xeancia, n\xe3o sabem para qu\xea serve.</p> <p>Bem, neste post quero compartilhar uma ideia bem bacana de como usar o OneDrive (qualquer um dos dois!) para sincronizar seus documentos com a nuvem, de modo a ter n\xe3o apenas um backup de seus arquivos mas tamb\xe9m poder acess\xe1-los de qualquer lugar.</p><!--more--><h2>O problema</h2> <p>Usu\xe1rios de Windows est\xe3o acostumados a usar a pasta Documentos (<code>C:\\Users\\<em>&lt;nome do usu\xe1rio&gt;</em>\\Documents</code>) para guardar seus arquivos \u2013 em particular aqueles criados pelos programas do Office e afins. O problema \xe9 que essa \xe9 uma pasta local (ou seja, existe apenas no computador) e, portanto, todo o seu conte\xfado pode ser perdido se a pasta for apagada ou se acontecer algo ao computador. Junte-se a isso o fato de que usu\xe1rios raramente se preocupam em fazer backups de seus dados e temos a receita para um desastre, s\xf3 esperando pela primeira oportunidade para acontecer.</p> <h2>A ideia</h2> <p>Agora, e se pud\xe9ssemos configurar o Windows para sincronizar automaticamente o conte\xfado de nossa pasta Documentos, de modo que toda e qualquer altera\xe7\xe3o fosse replicada para um banco de dados central na nuvem (acess\xedvel atrav\xe9s do <em>browser</em>) e para quaisquer outros computadores que eu venha a usar?</p> <p>Dessa forma, n\xe3o s\xf3 eu teria a seguran\xe7a de que meus dados est\xe3o guardados em outros locais al\xe9m do meu computador mas tamb\xe9m poderia acessar a \xfaltima vers\xe3o de um documento a partir de qualquer lugar (inclusive <a href="https://onedrive.live.com/about/pt-br/download/" target="_blank">a partir de smartphones</a>). Ou seja, poderia come\xe7ar um documento no escrit\xf3rio e continuar em casa a partir do mesmo ponto em que parasse, sem levar notebooks (ou pen drives) para l\xe1 e para c\xe1.</p> <p>Apesar de haver in\xfameras maneiras de se conseguir isso, escolhi usar o OneDrive for Business como exemplo neste post porque:</p> <ol> <li>Ele tem uma capacidade de armazenamento bem grande (tipicamente 1TB); e <li>Ele \xe9 gratuito para usu\xe1rios de Office 365, que muitas vezes nem sabem que ele existe. </li></ol> <p>Bom, hora de p\xf4r a m\xe3o na massa. Vamos come\xe7ar instalando o OneDrive. Ah, mesmo que voc\xea j\xe1 tenha o OneDrive em seu computador, n\xe3o deixe de ler a se\xe7\xe3o abaixo.</p> <h2>Instalando o OneDrive</h2> <p>Na verdade pode ser que voc\xea j\xe1 tenha o OneDrive instalado a\xed no seu computador, sabia? Isso porque desde o Windows 8 (incluindo Windows 10) o OneDrive vem pr\xe9-instalado como parte do sistema operacional. Por\xe9m, esse OneDrive que vem no Windows funciona apenas para as contas <strong>pessoais</strong> e n\xe3o reconhece o OneDrive for Business. Isso, contudo, vai mudar. A Microsoft est\xe1 desenvolvendo um novo cliente do OneDrive, o <a href="https://support.office.com/en-us/article/Improve-your-OneDrive-sync-experience-7af500d9-a18e-4abb-8450-b94f4e52c1a0" target="_blank">OneDrive Next Gen Sync Client</a> (ODNGSC). Um dos grandes benef\xedcios desse novo cliente \xe9 consolidar numa \xfanica aplica\xe7\xe3o o suporte aos dois tipos de conta do OneDrive: Pessoal e Business.</p> <p>A primeira coisa a se fazer, ent\xe3o, \xe9 <a href="http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=248256" target="_blank">baixar o novo cliente do OneDrive</a> e instal\xe1-lo em seu computador. Ao faz\xea-lo, voc\xea ir\xe1 substituir qualquer vers\xe3o anterior do OneDrive que porventura esteja instalada em seu computador \u2013 at\xe9 mesmo a vers\xe3o que veio pr\xe9-instalada no Windows 8/10.</p> <p>Pode ser que nada do que falei at\xe9 agora seja novidade para voc\xea, e que voc\xea j\xe1 esteja usando o OneDrive Next Gen Sync Client para sincronizar o OneDrive Pessoal. Nesse caso, pode pular a se\xe7\xe3o abaixo e <a href="#OD4B">ir direto para a configura\xe7\xe3o do OneDrive for Business</a>. Se ainda n\xe3o instalou o ODNGSC, continue lendo!</p> <p>Agora, se voc\xea j\xe1 tiver usando o ODNGSC n\xe3o apenas para a conta pessoal mas tamb\xe9m para sincronizar o OneDrive for Business (ou se voc\xea <strong>n\xe3o</strong> tem uma conta do OneDrive for Business) pode <a href="#FolderSync">pular direto para a parte mais importante</a> do post.</p> <h3>OneDrive Pessoal</h3> <p>Ao instalar o novo cliente do OneDrive, voc\xea ser\xe1 apresentado \xe0 tela abaixo. Nela, coloque o e-mail da sua Conta Microsoft (tipicamente um e-mail @hotmail.com, @live.com ou @outlook.com) que est\xe1 associada ao seu OneDrive.</p> <p><figure><img title="Janela inicial de configura&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive. Informe o e-mail da sua Conta Microsoft (1)" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Janela inicial de configura&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive. Informe o e-mail da sua Conta Microsoft (1)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/SNAGHTML1b5ded9.png" width="724" height="590"><figcaption>Janela inicial de configura\xe7\xe3o do OneDrive. Informe o e-mail da sua Conta Microsoft (1)</figcaption></figure>Fa\xe7a o login em sua Conta Microsoft. A seguir, ser\xe1 exibida a janela abaixo indicando em qual pasta no seu computador ser\xe1 sincronizado o OneDrive (1). Opcionalmente, voc\xea pode alterar o endere\xe7o padr\xe3o de sincroniza\xe7\xe3o (2). Isso \xe9 especialmente \xfatil se seu computador tiver dois HDs \u2013 um drive C pequeno (como um SSD) e um drive D maior (normalmente um HDD). Nesse caso, altere o local de sincroniza\xe7\xe3o e aponte para uma unidade local que tenha espa\xe7o suficiente para guardar seus documentos.</p> <p><figure><img title="Janela de configura&ccedil;&atilde;o do local de sincroniza&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive (1). Voc&ecirc; pode, tamb&eacute;m, alterar o local de sincroniza&ccedil;&atilde;o (2)" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Janela de configura&ccedil;&atilde;o do local de sincroniza&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive (1). Voc&ecirc; pode, tamb&eacute;m, alterar o local de sincroniza&ccedil;&atilde;o (2)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-24.png" width="724" height="590"><figcaption>Janela de configura\xe7\xe3o do local de sincroniza\xe7\xe3o do OneDrive (1). Voc\xea pode, tamb\xe9m, alterar o local de sincroniza\xe7\xe3o (2)</figcaption></figure>Agora \xe9 s\xf3 clicar no Avan\xe7ar (\u201c<em>Next</em>\u201d) e pronto! Estamos com o OneDrive Pessoal configurado!</p> <p><img title="Janela de conclus&atilde;o da instala&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive Pessoal" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Janela de conclus&atilde;o da instala&ccedil;&atilde;o do OneDrive Pessoal" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-25.png" width="724" height="590"></p> <p>Se voc\xea tiver uma conta do OneDrive for Business (normalmente associada a uma conta do Office 365) continue lendo a seguir. Sen\xe3o, <a href="#FolderSync">pule para a configura\xe7\xe3o das pastas</a>.</p> <h3><a name="OD4B"></a>OneDrive for Business</h3> <p>Com a conta pessoal configurada, podemos agora configurar a conta de neg\xf3cios. O primeiro passo \xe9 encontrar o \xedcone do OneDrive Pessoal na \xe1rea de notifica\xe7\xf5es do Windows (1) para, ent\xe3o, clicar em Configura\xe7\xf5es (\u201c<em>Settings</em>\u201d):</p> <p><figure><img title="Acesso &agrave; janela de op&ccedil;&otilde;es do OneDrive atrav&eacute;s do &iacute;cone na &aacute;rea de notifica&ccedil;&atilde;o" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Acesso &agrave; janela de op&ccedil;&otilde;es do OneDrive atrav&eacute;s do &iacute;cone na &aacute;rea de notifica&ccedil;&atilde;o" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-26.png" width="976" height="695"><figcaption>Acesso \xe0 janela de op\xe7\xf5es do OneDrive atrav\xe9s do \xedcone na \xe1rea de notifica\xe7\xe3o.</figcaption></figure>Na caixa de di\xe1logo de Configura\xe7\xf5es do OneDrive (abaixo) h\xe1 uma op\xe7\xe3o \u2013 novidade do ODNGSC \u2013 para adicionar uma \u201cconta de neg\xf3cios\u201d:</p> <p><figure><a href="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/SNAGHTMLf295ed.png"><img title="Janela de configura&ccedil;&otilde;es do OneDrive Next Gen Sync Client, com a op&ccedil;&atilde;o de acrescentar uma conta de neg&oacute;cios (1) (clique para ampliar)" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Janela de configura&ccedil;&otilde;es do OneDrive Next Gen Sync Client, com a op&ccedil;&atilde;o de acrescentar uma conta de neg&oacute;cios (1)" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/SNAGHTMLf295ed_thumb.png" width="452" height="484"></a><br><figcaption>Janela de configura\xe7\xf5es do OneDrive Next Gen Sync Client, com a op\xe7\xe3o de acrescentar uma conta de neg\xf3cios (1) (clique para ampliar)</figcaption></figure>Clique no bot\xe3o para adicionar uma conta de neg\xf3cios (1) e informe agora seu <strong>e-mail do Office 365</strong> O resto do processo \xe9 bem similar ao da conta pessoal.</p> <h2><a name="FolderSync"></a>Configurando o backup autom\xe1tico</h2> <p>Para concluir o processo, precisamos dizer ao Windows que nossas pastas locais de documentos dever\xe3o ser sincronizadas com o OneDrive. Para isso, vamos abrir a pasta local do OneDrive no Explorador de Arquivos. Se voc\xea tiver as duas contas (<em>Personal</em> e <em>Business</em>), escolha aquela que tem mais espa\xe7o.</p> <p>Agora crie dois subdiret\xf3rios (se n\xe3o existirem): Documentos e Imagens. Vamos usa-los para guardar nossos documentos e imagens, respectivamente, salvos no computador local.</p> <p><figure><img title="OneDrive for Business com dois novos subdiret&oacute;rios, Documentos e Imagens, onde iremos sincronizar nossos arquivos" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="OneDrive for Business com dois novos subdiret&oacute;rios, Documentos e Imagens, onde iremos sincronizar nossos arquivos" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/image.png" width="1552" height="949"><figcaption>OneDrive for Business com dois novos subdiret\xf3rios, Documentos e Imagens, onde iremos sincronizar nossos arquivos</figcaption></figure></p> <p>\xdaltima etapa (ufa!): Ainda no Explorador de Arquivos, v\xe1 \xe0 pasta do Computador (\u201cThis PC\u201d), clique com o direito na pasta de Documentos e selecione Propriedades:</p> <p><figure><img title="Clique com o bot&atilde;o direito na pasta Documentos e selecione Propriedades" style="border-left-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom-width: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px; border-top-width: 0px" border="0" alt="Clique com o bot&atilde;o direito na pasta Documentos e selecione Propriedades" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/SNAGHTML12f1537d.png" width="1547" height="1241"><figcaption>Clique com o bot\xe3o direito na pasta Documentos e selecione Propriedades</figcaption></figure></p> <p>Na aba Local (\u201cLocation\u201d), clique em Mover e aponte sua pasta de documentos para o respectivo subdiret\xf3rio que acabamos de criar no OneDrive. Quaisquer documentos que voc\xea porventura j\xe1 tenha no computador local ser\xe3o movidos para a pasta do OneDrive e, portanto, ser\xe3o copiados para a nuvem. Al\xe9m disso, daqui para a frente qualquer programa que queira abrir e/ou salvar documentos na pasta padr\xe3o de Documentos ir\xe1 usar automaticamente essa nova pasta no OneDrive.</p> <p><figure><img title="Aba Local da pasta de Documentos apontando para o subdiret&oacute;rio Documentos no OneDrive" style="border-top: 0px; border-right: 0px; background-image: none; border-bottom: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-left: 0px; display: inline; padding-right: 0px" border="0" alt="Aba Local da pasta de Documentos apontando para o subdiret&oacute;rio Documentos no OneDrive" src="https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/image6.png" width="548" height="724"><figcaption>Aba Local da pasta de Documentos apontando para o subdiret\xf3rio Documentos no OneDrive</figcaption></figure></p> <p>Pronto! Agora, nossos documentos estar\xe3o sempre sincronizados com a nuvem e com quaisquer outros computadores onde executarmos este mesmo procedimento. \xc9 uma maneira interessante de, por exemplo, replicar os arquivos entre os computadores de casa e do escrit\xf3rio, ou entre um desktop e um notebook.</p> <p><em>\u201cEi, e a pasta Imagens?\u201d</em></p> <p>Bem, repita o processo acima mas agora apontando para a pasta Imagens ao inv\xe9s da pasta Documentos. Dessa forma, voc\xea faz backup n\xe3o apenas dos seus documentos mas tamb\xe9m de suas fotos e outras imagens!</p> <h2>Conclus\xe3o</h2> <p>E a\xed, o que achou da dica? Agora voc\xea tem backup e sincroniza\xe7\xe3o multi-dispositivo para seus documentos! Legal, n\xe3o? </p> <p>N\xe3o deixe de comentar!</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>Um abra\xe7o,<br>Igor</p>', 'parent': u'0', 'excerpt': '', 'img_srcs': ['https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/SNAGHTML1b5ded9.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-24.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-25.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/image-26.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/SNAGHTMLf295ed_thumb.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/image.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/SNAGHTML12f1537d.png', 'https://www.tshooter.com.br/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/image6.png'], 'link': u'http://www.tshooter.com.br/2016/05/02/faca-backup-automatico-de-documentos-com-onedrive/', 'date': u'2016-05-02 11:49:18', 'slug': u'faca-backup-automatico-de-documentos-com-onedrive', 'title': u'Fa\xe7a backup autom\xe1tico de documentos com OneDrive', 'author': u'igoravl', 'taxanomies': {u'category': [u'Dicas'], u'language': [u'Portugu\xeas'], u'post_tag': [u'Office 365', u'OneDrive', u'OneDrive for Business', u'SharePoint']}, 'comments': True, 'wp_id': u'11781', 'type': u'post'}
